clinical_study.brief_title: Testing the Effect of a Warning About New Drugs
clinical_study.official_title: Testing the Effect of a Warning About New Drugs

lead_sponsor.agency: White River Junction Veterans Affairs Medical Center

collaborator.agency: Attorney General Consumer & Prescriber Education Grant

clinical_study.source: White River Junction Veterans Affairs Medical Center

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to test whether a new drug warning decreases enthusiasm for new drugs.

primary_outcome.measure: Hypothetical choice of old (vs. newer) drug

secondary_outcome.measure: Comprehension of the drug warning and drug information

arm_group.description: Survey contains information about when the drug was approved by the FDA (2009)and a directive warning (i.e., stating the issue and why it matters) for new drugs. This directive warning mentions that serious drug side effects may emerge only after the drug is already on the market, and the reader should ask their doctor there is an available drug with a longer track record.

Survey contains information about when the drug was approved by the FDA (2009) and a non-directive warning (i.e., just stating the issue) for new drugs. This non-directive warning mentions only that serious drug side effects may emerge only after the drug is already on the market.
Survey contains information about when the drug was approved by the FDA (2009) only.

intervention.intervention_name: Presentation of information about drug approval and level of warning
intervention.description: Presentation of information about date of drug approval with no new drug warning, a non-directive drug box warning or a directive drug box warning

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria
- Participants will be randomly selected from a research panel of more than 60,000 U.S. households (Knowledge Networks).
